ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HONG KONG INDUSTRIAL INVESTMENTS IN SINGAPORE


    1. Mr Lim Cheng Lock asked the Minister for Finance whether Hong Kong industrialists who have shown interest in industrial investments in Singapore have merely made enquiries from the Economic Development Board or whether they have made any commitments to establish factories in Singapore, and if he will make a statement on developments in this connection in the last two months.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, of the large number of Hong Kong industrialists who have recently approached the Economic Development Board with investment proposals, 86 have entered into a serious commitment to establish a factory in Singapore. This commitment constitutes either site acquisition or site and building acquisition. In addition, most of these have entered into partnerships with Singapore industrialists and,

Column: 306

in a good number of instances, orders for the purchase of equipment and machinery have been placed.

    The total capital investment of these 86 enterprises, excluding the cost of land, comes to $49 million. Being largely labour intensive, they will provide many jobs for this sum, 8,000 in the initial phase and 13,600 when at full production.

    The 86 firms in terms of size of capital investment may be classified as follows: 

            Investment of $ 1 million or more                  17

            Investment of $ ½ million to under $1 million      13

            Investment of $200,000 to under $½ million         44

            Under $200,000                                     12

                                                               --  

                        Total                                  86

                                                               ==


    The projects cover a wide field. To mention only a few, they include building hardware, electronics, pharmaceuticals, clocks and watches, toys, various machinery and engineering products, synthetic fibres, and printing and publishing. The figures I give represent the position at the latest count. The number will no doubt increase as the more recent arrivals firm up their investment arrangements.

    One feature of these new projects is that the larger part of the output is produced for the export market. Hong Kong industrialists are reputed for their fine competitive performance in world markets. They are the kind of entrepreneurs any sensible developing country would be glad to have, and Singapore extends a warm welcome to them. We shall do all we can to make their ventures in Singapore successful and profitable.

PRIMARY SCHOOL LEAVING EXAMINATION IN 1967
(Secondary school places and postings)


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Education whether all students who pass the Primary School

Column: 307

Leaving Examination this year will be given places in secondary schools; whether he is aware of the many cases in previous years where students were posted to secondary schools far away from their homes; and what steps he will take to prevent a similar situation this year.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker. Sir, it is expected that, subject to adequate provision in the 1968 Budget for education, every Primary VI pupil in Singapore who is successful in the Primary School Leaving Examination this year will be given a place in a secondary academic, technical or vocational school. However, it is obviously not possible to meet the wishes of every parent in regard to the choice of a particular school. No system of allocation can please everyone.

    The present system of allocation for the Chinese and English streams, which has been in operation since 1965, is processed by computers. It is based on the choice exercised by the parents and the results of the Primary School Leaving Examination. Under this system the vast majority of successful candidates are posted to schools of their own choice. For example, in 1966, out of a total of 32,602 successful candidates, 21,074 were posted to schools according to their first choice, and 6,036 were posted according to their second choice. Only 5,492 or 16.8 per cent were posted to schools other than their choice, because all vacancies in the schools of their choice were taken up by other candidates with better results in the Primary School Leaving Examination. Among the 5,492 pupils who failed to secure a place under their first as well as second choice, about 5,200 applied for transfers. Of these, 4,600 were approved and only 600 could not be approved, because all vacancies in schools near their homes had already been taken up by other pupils with better examination results.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, just now the Minister has said that, subject to adequate provision in the 1968 Budget, it appears that all students who passed the Primary School Leaving Examination would be given places. Could the Minister be more explicit in explaining the phrase "subject to adequate provision in the 1968 Budget"?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member for Punggol knows exactly what I mean. There is no need to explain in further detail.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Can the Minister say whether it is correct that, should there be inadequate provision in the 1968 Budget, all students may not be given places in the secondary schools?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Correct.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: The Minister for Finance has already answered for me.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I completely agree with the Minister for Education that the Government cannot, of course, accede to the request of the parents to send their children to the schools of their choice. But at the end of the year of the school term, there is a great mess in the postings of students from one school to another school. I can quote an example. For instance, if a student is staying in Jurong, he is posted to St. Anthony's School, whereas, on the other hand, a student staying somewhere in Bras Basah Road is posted to Jurong School.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ho, can we have your supplementary question, please?

    Mr Ho See Beng: What I am complaining about is the posting system. Although the Ministry of Education -

    Mr Speaker: If you want to make a complaint, Mr Ho, there are other procedural methods available to you. But if you have a supplementary question, please frame it quickly.

Column: 309



    Mr Ho See Beng: Will the Minister give an assurance to the House that after having posted the students to a school very far away from their homes and that if the parents are able to find vacancies in another school which is very close to their homes, the Ministry of Education will rectify the wrong postings? This is the question I am asking the Minister.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is precisely what my Ministry has been doing for the past few years. For instance, early this year 5,200 students applied for transfer, and of this number, 4,600 were approved. That, I am sure, answers the point of the Member.

    Mr S. Rajoo (Farrer Park): According to the Minister, it seems that even if adequate provision is made in 1968, there is a possibility of a certain number of children being posted to schools very far away from their homes. Under such circumstances, will the Minister give an assurance that where the poor parents cannot send their children to distant schools, the Ministry will consider giving a transport bursary to the children?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the affected pupils can always apply for a transport bursary, and if they merit such an award, it will be given.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not satisfied with the Minister's answer to my question asking him to clarify the very phrase he used in his reply just now. Is it or is it not the policy of the Government to provide secondary education to all those students who have passed the P.S.L.E.? The next question is this. Is the Minister satisfied with the system of posting successful students in the P.S.L.E. and, if not, will he take steps to change the system since, over a period of two years, more than 5,000, as he has just mentioned, have been posted elsewhere? Thirdly, -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ng, I think we had better have answers to your first two questions before we come to the third question. Mr Ong?

Column: 310



    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, taking the second question first. I am quite satisfied with the present system. But if the Member for Punggol can suggest a better system, I am prepared to consider it.

    As for the first question, while it is the policy of the Government in the past few years to provide a place for every student who has passed the P.S.L.E., the position cannot be the same for all time. Much depends on the economy of the country and the state of its finances. I am sure if the finances of the State permit, we will provide places for all those who can pass the P.S.L.E. Otherwise, that is that.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: As regards my suggestion to rectify the system -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ng, I am afraid i will not let you go into that. I called you for your third supplementary.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Yes, Sir. My third question is this. Just now the Minister has mentioned that out of 5,000-plus students, 4,000 odd were given places as a result of applications for transfer, is the Minister aware that quite a long period of study days has been lost as a result of these students applying for transfers to schools nearer to their homes?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, a certain amount of study time might have been lost in the process of applying for a transfer, but that cannot be helped. I do not think the time lost is in any way excessive.

STOPPING OF AUTOMATIC PROMOTION IN PRIMARY SCHOOLS


    3. Mr Lee Teck Him asked the Minister for Education whether he will consider stopping automatic promotion in primary schools especially in promotions to Primary 2 and Primary 3.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the practice of automatic promotion was, in fact, abolished in 1959. Schools at present may retain pupils in

Column: 311

Primaries 3, 4, 5 and 6. However, retention at Primaries 1 and 2 level is at present not possible for the following reasons.

    Firstly, it is the policy of the Government to ensure that every Singapore citizen who is of school-going age is given a place in school. As the number of such children is enormous, it is not possible to retain pupils in Primary 1 without depriving some of these school-going children of their places.

    Secondly, it is also considered unsound by educationists to retain pupils at the end of the first year in school for psychological reasons.

    Thirdly, the Lim Tay Boh Commission of inquiry recommended that the first three years of primary school work should be planned as a single coordinated unit and the final assessment of a child's progress should be made at the end of the third year.

    Mr Lee Teck Him (Tiong Bahru)(In Mandarin): Sir, the Minister has just now given us an explanation. But I am not quite satisfied with that, because we know that pupils in Primary 1 and Primary 2 are not capable of thinking for themselves. So we should not allow them to be promoted automatically if they are not qualified. We should know that studying is like building a house. In order to build a multi-storey house, the foundations should be deeper and the piling should be stronger. The deeper the piling, the stronger will be the structure.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Lee, you must have heard what I told Mr Ho and Mr Ng a few minutes ago. Can we have a supplementary question, if you have one, and not a debate, please?

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, thank you very much. I would like to add something more. If the foundation is not soundly laid, no tall building can be constructed thereon. So if Primary 1 and Primary 2, which should be construed as the foundation of a building, are not soundly laid,

Column: 312

then how can any high structures be built on that basis? I would like to ask the Minister whether my explanation is correct.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have enumerated a number of reasons why retention at Primary 1 and Primary 2 is not possible at this stage. If the Member thinks that retention at Primaries 1 and 2 level is desirable, then that is his opinion. But it runs counter to the views of educationists.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, if a student in Primary 1 cannot make the grade and you promote him to Primary 2 and then to Primary 3, can the Minister say how he expects this student to cope with the work in Primary 3?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the first year, Primary 1, and also Primary 2 to a large extent, teaching is mainly oral. I do not see why a reasonably intelligent child cannot improve in the second or third year. Perhaps the Member for Bras Basah should persuade parents of children failing in the first year, i.e., Primary 1, to pay more attention to their children's studies.

LEGALISATION OF ABORTION
(Representations by organisations)


    4. Mrs Devan Nair asked the Minister for Health if he will sympathetically consider any representations made or to be made to him by religious and other organisations against the proposed legalisation of abortion.

    Mr Lim Kim San (Acting Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am always very sympathetic to other views on any question. I would like to inform the House that representations from persons or organisations are now being received, and I can assure the House that the views of interested persons and organisations on the proposed legislation can be heard at the Select Committee stage after the principles of the Bill have been debated in Parliament at its Second Reading.

Column: 313



    Mr Ho See Beng: If I understood the Minister correctly, the Government is going to proceed with legalised abortion. Can the Minister clarify?

    Mr Speaker: I think it is obvious, Mr Ho, that the Minister went further than that. He even said that the Bill, if it passes the Second Reading, will be referred to a Select Committee.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to make it clear that I never for one deny responsibility for the Ministry of Health in any way.

AMENDMENT TO CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND ORDINANCE


    5. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Minister for Labour whether he will consider amending the Central Provident Fund Ordinance to enable contributors to withdraw monies due to them from the Fund if (a) they are disabled without being permanently incapacitated from ever continuing in employment; or, (b) they are unemployed for periods of less than two years and are unable to establish that they will never be re-employed in order to enable such persons who so desire to start their own business and thereby cease being burdens on the welfare services of the Republic.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Central Provident Fund Ordinance was introduced for the specific purpose of making provision for employees in their old age, and it was not originally intended that they should be allowed to withdraw before they reached the age of 55. However, provision has been made to permit withdrawals on death or where it appears unlikely that an employee will contribute to the Fund again. If the request made by the hon. Member to allow withdrawals for the purpose of starting their own business in the two specific cases mentioned by him is permitted, it would completely defeat the intention behind the Ordinance. Further, it is pertinent to point out that if withdrawals are permitted for the purpose, their is no guarantee that the sums received, which are generally not substantial, will not be lost or frittered away. If this were to happen, the workers concerned would not have anything to protect them in their old age and they would, in all probability, become a burden on the welfare services of the Republic. In the

Column: 315

circumstances, it is considered desirable that no change should be made to the law at present.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: If a person leaves Singapore permanently and is not coming back, it is quite possible for him to withdraw his money from the Central Provident Fund provided that he can show proof that he is not coming back to stay in Singapore any more.

I think on this aspect there must be flexibility in the application of the C.P.F. Ordinance.

PUBLIC ASSISTANCE AND T.B. TREATMENT ALLOWANCES
(Stopping of payments to non-citizens)


    6. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs in how many cases were payments of public assistance and T.B. Treatment Allowances stopped, because the recipients were found to be non-citizens, following the introduction of the new laminated identity cards.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: As from 24th June, 1959, all new cases of recipients of public assistance have been confined only to Singapore citizens. However, between the period of 5th May, 1966, when new laminated identity cards were introduced, and 30th September, 1967, 460 cases of assistance were withdrawn from the public assistance scheme as they were non-citizens.

    As for T.B. Treatment Allowances, there is no case of stoppage of such an allowance to non-citizens during the period 5th May, 1966, to 30th September, 1967, as all recipients of this allowance are confined only to Singapore citizens.

    Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson): Can the Minister say what amount of money has been saved during the period stated?

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: It is not easy to give the exact figure. But in the 460 cases, taking an average of $36 per case a month, this will work out to approximately $18,500 per month.

MALAYSIAN-INDONESIAN COMMON SPELLING SYSTEM FOR
MALAY LANGUAGE


    7. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs what is the Government's attitude to the proposed Malaysian-Indonesian common spelling system for the Malay Language.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: The Government of Singapore has an open mind on the proposed Malaysian-Indonesian common spelling system for the Malay language. Singapore is not represented in the Committee set up to work out a common Malaysian-Indonesian common spelling system, but has her own Spelling Committee of 11 persons appointed on 26th January, 1966, by the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs, to study and bring up to date the Malay spelling system in the Republic. The Committee consists of the Republic's prominent Malay scholars. At present, the Committee is studying the report of the Malaysian-Indonesian Spelling Committee with a view to improving its own spelling system.

"JAMES BOND" TYPE OF FILMS
(Unhealthy influence on children)


    8. Mrs Devan Nair asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs whether he is aware that many parents in Singapore are disturbed by the unhealthy influence on their children of the "James Bond" type of film and if he will consider taking steps to prohibit the viewing of such films by children.

Column: 318



    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Board of Film Censors responsible for the censoring of films has informed me that, so far, no complaints have been received from any quarter in regard to the exhibition of the "James Bond" type of films.

    Whether such a type of films exerts an unhealthy influence is a matter of personal opinion. Therefore, if parents consider that such films do, in fact, have an unhealthy influence on their children, they should play their part in discouraging their children from seeing these films, and not prevent the exhibition of such films for the enjoyment of other sections of the public if the films are unobjectionable. Further, in our multi-racial, multi-cultural and multi-religious society, Government feels that it will not be right for any one section of the community to impose its standard of morality on other sections of the community.

    To prevent only children from seeing such films will require films and audience to be officially classified. So far no official film classification has been made in Singapore. Although there have been prolonged discussions with exhibitors and distributors on the subject of official film classification in Singapore, this has not been adopted not only because film exhibitors and distributors are against such classification, but also because there are practical difficulties in implementing a film classification system in Singapore where the bulk of the cinema-going public consists of the younger generation. It is because of the absence of official film classification and the awareness of the fact that the majority of film goers are youths and children that the Board of Film Censors is very careful to ensure that all films passed for public exhibition are suitable for the viewing of both adults and children alike. As a matter of fact, many films which would otherwise be perfectly all right in their entirety for adults only have to be cut, because of the fact that they would be accessible to children on release. The care taken applies to all

PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
(Tender and contract system)


    11. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether the present system adopted by the Public Works Department of inviting tenders and giving out contracts is satisfactory; and whether he plans to reorganise it.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, to answer this question, I will have to outline briefly the tender system adopted by the Public Works Department.

    Tenders for public works projects are normally invited by means of tender notifications published in the Government Gazette and in cases where the

Column: 321

value of the project is estimated to exceed $50,000, a tender notice is also advertised in the Press. Only registered contractors are selected and may tender for public works. These contractors are selected and classified on the basis of sound finance, good experience and satisfactory performance for past work, technical knowledge and availability of plant and good organising ability.

    Registered contractors call personally with their registration cards to collect the various tender documents, such as forms of tenders, specifications, bills of quantities and drawings. To safeguard the secrecy of the competitive nature of the tender system, all tenders must be enclosed in a sealed envelope and deposited in the locked tender box provided for the purpose before the closing time for receipt of tenders. At the appointed time on the closing date, a Tenders Opening Committee opens the tender box, collects the tenders and opens them in the presence of all the members. It is the duty of the Tenders Opening Committee to number and initial each and every tender received and to prepare a precis of tenders containing such information as the names of the tenderers and the amounts of tenders. The precis and the tender forms are then processed and recommendations made to the appropriate Tenders Board for consideration and decision.

    In the case of minor works valued at less than $10,000, consideration for acceptance or rejection is undertaken by an Assistant Director of the Public Works. After approval has been given by the appropriate Tenders Board or the Assistant Director of Public Works, checks are made to ensure that the rates and the bills of quantities and schedule of rates are arithmetically correct. These approvals are then conveyed to the successful tenderers by means of letters of acceptance, and action is then taken to prepare and sign the necessary contract documents.

    The system, as I have outlined, has worked satisfactorily and there is no reason why it should be changed.
